items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: What is your favorite holiday? Tom: one where I get to meet lots of different people. Jerry: What was the most number of people you have ever met during a holiday? Tom: Hard to keep a count. Maybe 25. Jerry: Which holiday was that? Tom: I think it was Australia. Jerry: Do you still talk to the people you met? Tom: Not really. The interactions are usually short-lived but it's fascinating to learn where people are coming from and what matters to them. Jerry: Yea, me too. I feel like God often puts strangers in front of you, and gives you an opportunity to connect with them in that moment in deeply meaningful ways. Do you ever feel like you know things about strangers without them telling you? Tom: what do you mean? Jerry: I think it's like a 6th sense, often seen as "cold readings" to people, but can be remarkably accurate. I once sat next to a man in a coffee and I felt a pain in my back. I asked the stranger if he had a pain. It turns out that he did in the exact spot, and said he pulled a muscle while dancing at a party. I had never met the man before and never saw him again. Tom: Wow! That's interesting, borderline spooky. Jerry: There's this practice called "Treasure Hunting" that's kind of a fun game you play in a public place. There's a book called "The Ultimate Treasure Hunt" that talks about it. You use your creativity to imagine people you will meet, and you write down a description, then you associate them with a positive message or encouraging word. Maybe you saw a teenage boy in a red hat at the shopping mall in your imagination, then while at the mall, you may find someone who matches that description. You show that you have a message for him and that you have a message for a boy in a red hat. You then give him a message of kindness or whatever was on your heart. You have no idea, sometimes you meet someone who is having a really hard day, and it brings them to tears to have a stranger show them love.
items.question: What was the most number of people Tom has met during a holiday?

Tom: I'm working on a theory. Why does the lotus spring to mind? Jerry: Nice! Lotus looks pretty cool and It has some delightful vibe. So what is this research about? Tom: Oh, it's not research! Just a personal theory. I think that flower preferences are more revealing of personality than people appreciate. Jerry: Interesting! Whats your favorite flower? Tom: The gerbera. It's like a cartoon flower. As if you drew "flower" with a crayon and then it came to life. Jerry: Nice, i would love know more about your theory. Like how you can deduce personality from flower preference. Tom: Ok, step 1 is, you ask someone what their favourite flower is. Pretty much like what we just did. Does that make sense so far? Jerry: yes. Tom: Cool. Step 2: talk with the person some more, and ask them some more questions, and gradually develop a sense of what they're like, over the course of maybe two to five years. And voila. Jerry: Hehe, i think you should publish this someday :) Tom: Why thank you, that's a wonderful idea!

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hello, how are you? Tom: I'm great, thanks. I just ate a delicious breakfast, which always sets the day up right. Jerry: Yes, breakfast is the most important meal of the day! What did you have? I woke up late so unfortunately I only had the chance to grab an apple to go. Tom: I had eggs and hash browns. Way less healthier than your apple, I'm afraid! Jerry: Eggs are an excellent source of protein and hash browns certainly are yummy! üôÇ Tom: Ha, that's true. If you could only eat one food forever, what would it be? Jerry: That's a tough question. I feel like my answer would have to be carrots. Although, I would be afraid of turning orange after a few weeks! What about you? Tom: Yeah, turning orange would be a drawback! That turns my mind to nutrition so I suddenly want to say Soylent or one of those other "complete foods", which I think defeats the purpose of the question. I'm in a muddle! Jerry: Very true. If you said an everything pizza, you could just pick off the toppings you didn't want or eat only the toppings you would want for the day. Tom: BRILLIANT. I love it. Jerry: All of this talk about food is making me hungry. Do you know any good places to eat for lunch? Tom: That depends. What sort of food do you feel like? Jerry: Anything that is the color green. Tom: Oh, too easy! Try the Green Hut, they have franchises everywhere. All their food is green and the plates are green too.
items.question: What did Tom have for breakfast?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hello! How are you doing üôÇ Tom: I'm great! How's your day going? Jerry: Pretty good! I'm going to a class later in the afternoon. Tom: Oh that is cool! What class? Are you working part time? Jerry: No, I'm working full time! It's a sewing class at a makerspace near my office What about you? Do you work full or part time? Tom: Oh that is awesome! For some reason I assumed it was a college class, but a sewing class sounds way better! I work full time, but I take pottery classes from time to time! Jerry: Yup! I work in a technical role so I like to take arts and crafts-type classes now and then üôÇ Pottery sounds like a lot of fun. Tom: I feel you on that! My family is also very into tea Mostly from tea from china. Tom: I would love to build one, once I acquire the skills to! What kind of tea is your favorite? Jerry: Hmm I'm not sure, I just get them from a Chinese supermarket haha You seem really knowledgeable about the different kinds of teas üôÇ What made you develop this interest? Tom: I actually found a youtube channel called <REDACTED_TERM> that I like a lot. You should check it out! The host talks about all kinds of different teas. Jerry: Oh cool! What are your favorite channels to watch? Tom: Hi! Are you planning something fun for Thanksgiving?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Wow, hello. Can't believe we are finally talking! Tom: Yeah, sorry for the long gap! I heard you took a break and were travelling around the world. How was the travel? Jerry: It was an interesting trip. I got to see some exotic places. For example, I hiked the Son Doong cave in Vietnam. It's the biggest and deepest cave in the world. Tom: Great! Vietnam is still in my TODO bucket list. Did you also visit cambodia and other neighboring places? Jerry: Yes. Laos and Cambodia are the two neighboring countries. Cambodia has an exotic culture. They sell spiders, scorpions, and grasshoppers as street food! It took a lot of courage for me to try them. Tom: Hehe! How long was the stay? Jerry: 10 days in total, and 5 of them were spent in the cave. What have I missed at work in those days? Tom:  Great! Good time to be back. We are still in planning phase and haven't fully aligned on the projects to tackle for next quarter.reat! Good time to be back. We are still in planning phase and haven't fully aligned on the projects to tackle for next quarter. Jerry: Oh, so you are already planning for the next quarter. This whole team is always living the future. Tom: Hehe, yeah! It seems like the quarter is being pushed earlier than from where it starts üôÇ I like these planning sessions. It makes me feel more confident about the work I am doing. Jerry: Yeah. Some people underestimate the importance of planning, but I think it's very important to have the correct plan. Executing the wrong plan is terrible. Also, planning is fun. You can stack up so many ideas and get great feedbacks.
items.question: Which cave did Jerry hike in Vietnam?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hello. How's your week coming along? Tom: It's great, thanks. I'm trying to learn how to make croissants. Jerry: Wow that's interesting. I have baked cookies, but croissants seem much more sophisticated. Did you make any progress? Tom: I've done them once or twice so far, but they haven't been flakey enough. I'm trying to figure out why. What kind of cookies have you made? Jerry: Mint chocolate chips. I think your croissants not being flakey could have something to do with your oven's temperature. Tom: Ah, good thought, thanks! Jerry: Have you thought about melting some chocolate into your croissants? They don't have to be something unhealthy. For example, melted dark chocolate is good for the heart, and makes the resulting croissants taste much better. Tom: Now that is a good idea. I'll give it a try next time. Would you say you have a sweet tooth? Jerry: Yes. When my top favorite food looks like: cookies, M&M, danish cheese, etc., I know that I have a thing for sweet food. But who doesn't love sweet food? How about you? Tom: Some people don't! But yeah, me too, I think I'd eat pastries all the time if I could get away with it. Jerry: Yeah I'm afraid I wouldn't. I feel very guilty every time I gulp down an ice cream. But hey, these days there are many types of guilt-free sweet food. For example, there's this ice cream brand called <REDACTED_TERM>. It's only 320 calories a pint. And yes, it preserves most of the normal sweet flavors. Tom: Wow! The last time I paid attention to that sort of stuff was when <REDACTED_TERM> was being marketed as a fat substitute, and caused all sorts of crazy stomach upsets.
items.question: What type of cookies has Jerry baked?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: hey, what's up? Tom: What do you think about human like chat bots? Jerry: I can't wait for them to be great conversationalists! Tom: Yep, we seemed to have made some great progress over last few years. Do you think the positives outweigh the negatives. Jerry: are there even any negatives? what are they? Tom: Like impersorsination? Though it sounds far fetched :) Jerry: People can already impersonate other people though! I think it'd be great to have bots to converse with. Tom: True that! Some of these bots are very engaging and funny. They are now good at even sarcasm I wonder how far are we from the time these bots start giving monologues :) Jerry: What do you think are the big advantages? Like personal assistants? Tom: I think it can take many different forms as a product. The research implication is also huge! It will signify how AI research has progressed so far and better place to tackle more futuristic problems üôÇ Sort of like stepping on the moon üôÇ I might be overselling it here üòõ Jerry: No, I agree -- it's such an exciting time to be alive to get to witness all this and be a part of it. I wonder if I'll be able someday to get a chatbot to just auto-suggest conversations for me. Tom: The current auto-suggestions already do pretty good üôÇ Jerry: Yeah those are actually really good for a few words! I'm imagining like it comes up with a whole conversational response, like a default template. Tom: haha, pretty far fetched üôÇ Nice having this conversation with you! Jerry: Same with you!
items.question: What does Jerry think about human-like chatbots?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Do you believe in miracles? Tom: Lol. No. I know too many people whose lives suck. Jerry: Should we be helping them, so it sucks less?\ Tom: It's too many of them out there. You help who you can. Regardless, I wouldn't say I believe in miracles - well, if I got promoted next cycle I might change my mind. Jerry: Haha... Well, it sounds like career is really important to you. What matters to you the most in life? Tom: Right now, not much. It's unclear. Career is a good fallback because you get told what good means and you act accordingly. I haven't gone through the process of shaping my values. What about you? Jerry: I'd say that I want to live for the best possible world in my lifetime. It's probably a result of my playing too many video games as a child. Tom: We didn't have electricity growing up. Explains a lot. Lol. Jerry: Does not having had electricity help you empathize more with people of differing backgrounds and/or makes you feel a bit a distance from those who don't understand? Tom: It makes it easier to empathise with people who grew up lacking things. Not sure it makes me empathise with people in general. Where did you grow up? Jerry: I grew up in the United States, but my parents were immigrants and ended up being scammed of all their money, so we moved to Taiwan to live with family for a little bit. Tom: ALL THEIR MONEY? By a person or an organisation? Jerry: I was kind of too young to really understand, but apparently there are people who scam Asian immigrants into investing in their own restaurant business. I know that the other part of it was that my mom got sick/hospitalized, and we didn't have insurance. To be honest, I don't really know what really happened versus what my parents want people to think. I just know that one minute I was in the US, and then they put me on a plane to Taiwan, and I never saw my stuff again. In some ways, it made me more sentimental.
items.question: Where did Jerry's family move after being scammed?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hi. Tom: Okay...so I need someone to help me though a scenario I've been pondering. Jerry: Sure, whats the scenario? Tom: My partner's former friend invited me for lunch (they are not in good books right now). But during their friendship I formed an independent bond with the other person because we all used to hang out a lot. Now I feel like I have to take sides. Jerry: That's a tough scenario to be in üôÇ I firmly believe in talking this through with your partner. Though i don't know the specifics of why things went bad between your partner and his friend, but I believe things can always improve between friends. Tom: I hope they do. Getting older already means smaller circles. It sucks to lose friends for arbitrary reasons. That's good advice though. I fear raising the issue might sound like treason. Lol. Jerry: True about that! I also think time helps to heal certain situations. So may be doing nothing is the best way forward. Tom: AKA avoiding all texts from everyone? Jerry: Nope, that would be extreme. May be just putting some balance between the two options. Tom: People always say to find a balance but never say what the balance is. It's used so often that it's vacuous. Jerry: Right, I guess that's because there is no one answer to this. It depends on what you value more and some factors around you. Also, life won't be interesting if others are figuring things out for you üòâ Tom: Lol. I'm finna be single. Jerry: Hehe, everyone is much finer being single üôÇ

I moved here a few years ago to get out of the extreme cold. I do not care for bundling up and having to wear so many layers just to go buy eggs at the store. Tom: Oh nice! Where did you live before? Jerry: Upstate New York. We got a foot of snow every week during my last winter there. I am so glad to not have to shovel snow now. Tom: New york! Nice! Best place to live üôÇ .. right, except for the cold! Jerry: Very beautiful during all the seasons but yes, summer and winter can get extreme! Tom: Anyways, i guess we should better hurry up to get the goodies. I remember last time they ran out of it. Jerry: Very true. Which MK were they in again? Tom: The one in our floor. I will get by your desk and we can walk there. Jerry: Sounds good, thanks!

Jerry: I go to the gym and run until I find enough fun. Tom: cool! I've started to run a bit as well not long distances though, just a couple miles. Jerry: A couple of miles is very impressive. items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: hello there, how is it going? Tom: Pretty great. I just won a pingpong game. What about you? Jerry: that's nice. I am just working on some documentation. Do you play pingpong often? Tom: No, very rarely. It's kind of amazing that I won, but I'm still taking credit for it. Jerry: thats very impressive then, congrats! Tom: Haha thank you, I guess I'm just a natural. What's your favourite game? Jerry: I really like to play tennis, badminton and racquetball. I don't really get a chance to play them often though, specially racquetball. Tom: What's racquetball like? From context clues, I'm guessing that it involves hitting a ball with a racquet. Jerry: well, it's like a cage match of tennis. The main difference is that both players play in the same 'court' and the ball is smashed against a wall instead of passing it over a net into the opponent's court. Kind of like playing pingpong vs the table. Tom: Wow! A cage match! Does it get physical? Jerry: it depends haha, there is a lot of bumping into each other to run after the ball, and sometimes the ball hits you too. Overall it feels like a super fast paced version of tennis, really tiring! Tom: That sounds fun. I think of tennis itself as being really athletic and tiring, so I don't think it's a sport for me, though! Jerry: ping pong can get quite intensive too! I guess short ping pong sessions are not that tiring though. Wanna have a match? Tom: What a good idea, I'd love to! Tom: Show me your anger!!!! Jerry: Fuckkkkkkk!!!!

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hey, how's it going? Tom: It's good! How is your day? Jerry: My day is good. A bit sad that it gets dark so early but oh well. Did you do anything fun over the weekend? items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: What's your name? Tom: My name is pikachu. it‚Äôs nice to meet you! What are you up to this month? Jerry: Nice to meet you pikachu! pikachu, pikachu, pikachu? items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: What was the most difficult thing you experienced this past year? Jerry: I just released a book on <REDACTED_TERM> to help people process the past 12 months and start the new year with a fresh outlook üôÇ Tom: Great! It goes through accomplishments, passions, understanding, forgiveness, with each day a different theme. Tom: Wow! Sounds amazing if we practice that! I think the idea does have some potential. Jerry: We created a scholarship for leaders from <REDACTED_TERM> to visit an international institute at <REDACTED_TERM> for which there was no African representation. I have a private practice. You? Jerry: Thats pretty cool! I'm a sofa tester in cupertino. Tom: I'm not sure I know what that is. Jerry: well its very simple, I test how comfortable sofas are. Tom: Lol. Not to be elitist but...that's a real job? Jerry: Yeah! It is a very demanding job, requires a carefully crafted set of skills. They pay is really good too.
items.question: Where does Tom work?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hello. Deja Vu. Tom: what does that mean? Jerry: It's French for "already seen." I know it's used when you see something for the second time or you have the feeling that something has happened before and you're re-experiencing it. Tom: Interesting. I get that feeling sometimes. It just feels that the event is replaying. Wonder why it happens? Jerry: I think it's your mind lapsing somehow. Tom: How do you know so much about this French phrase? Jerry: I thought it was common. I hear it a lot in popular culture - movies music etc. Jay Z has a song called Deja Vu, so does Beyonce. So I looked it up one time. It's one of those phrases that was carried over exactly to english like "etcetera" "vice versa" "savior faire" and so on. I like cool word origin facts. Tom: yeah... that's pretty insightful. Never thought of etcetera that way before. Jerry: My favourite word origins are gymnasium and jazz. Tom: wdym by word origins here? Jerry: First usage and original meaning. Gymnasium meant place of nakedness and had very little to do with working out. Jazz comes from jism which means semen and was originally sporadic sex music now it's elitist, high art. Tom: Very interesting. I learned a lot in this conversation today üôÇ Jerry: You got any cool facts? Tom: My friend used to tell me this and found it funny - Mosquitos have 47 teeths. Jerry: That was quite a laughter!!! Tom: Tell me a joke! Jerry: Google for that:)
items.question: What is Jerry‚Äôs favorite word origin?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hey, how are you? Tom: Pretty good. I just drank this new hint water. so good. Jerry: ohh, what kind of "hint" did it have? Tom: watermelon. Jerry: nice, I love watermelon. But, I prefer normal water over flavored one. Flavored water has too synthetic flavor. Tom: I see. Yeah some are pretty strange. Jerry: Talking about strange flavors, what is the weirdest tasting thing you have tried? Tom: lol I tried this tangerine walnut icecream that was super weird. items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hi there. When did you first realize you wanted to be a pastry chef? Tom: Who said I want to be a pastry chef?... haha. Jerry: Darn it! I hoped I‚Äôd guess right. What do you actually do for work? Tom: I'm actually a cake chef, so not far off! Creepy how good that guess was.... Are you psychic? Jerry: I had a strong intuitive feeling connected to pastries when we started chatting, but that might have been because I‚Äôm hungry. Tom: haha you're too funny! Perhaps instead of mind-reading powers, you have the ability to feel the auras of foods that have come and gone... Jerry: Hahah love it. Do you have a specialty or favourite type of cake? Tom: Chocolate cake + vanilla icing is the all time best! And I have the authority to say that! How about you? Have a favorite? Jerry: Ok this is a bit shameful to admit, but I love a classic carrot cake. Tom: No shame in that! Best part is you can claim you are eating vegetables as you enjoy it! What do you do for work? Jerry: I‚Äôm a professional dancer. Tom: Woah! Very cool! What style of dance? Jerry: I trained in contemporary and jazz, so I can pick up work in commercials and film clips in between stage shows. So it ends up being all sorts of styles. Tom: Oh wow! Sounds like a very dynamic kind of work which is nice. I make a lot of the same cakes, day in day out. Jerry: Yes, it's different every week, and I love that. Are you ever tempted to try crazy new cakes just to see what would happen?
items.question: What type of cake does Tom prefer?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Morning! How are you? Tom: I am doing well. Do you have any plans for the holidays? Jerry: I'll be in Mexico for New Years but for Christmas I'll likely be at work. Yourself? Tom: I don't have any special plans. I will just stay at home with my family. How come you have to work on Christmas? Jerry: I traveled a lot the last few months so I'm currently making up for it! Tom: I see. Where did you go? Jerry: Mozambique! You ever been? Tom: I have not. I have only been to Uganda in Africa. Jerry: What did you do in Uganda? Travelling to Uganda is an extreme sport depending on where you go. Tom: I was working on a volunteer project to build a school and I traveled around a bit by myself after. It was more than 10 years ago, so it must have changed a lot. Jerry: Was the project through a church group? Tom: No, it was using a non-profit organization. They do these kinds of volunteer projects all over the world. Jerry: Oh nice. What is it called? I've always meant to volunteer through one but I haven't had it in my radar yet. Tom: It was called IJGD. It's a German organization, but they have local partners all over the world. I was living in Germany at the time. Jerry: You lived in Germany? I almost went to college there and decided to come to America instead. Tom: Yes, I grew up in Germany. Jerry: I grew up in Computers.

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hello! Tom: There is sports tournament (badminton + tennis + basketball) organized by google next week. Would you like to volunteer for these events? Jerry: what does a volunteer do? Tom: Volunteers have to book the place before the event, send out details of the event to participants, handle some logistics and ensure everything goes smoothly. It will be fun! Jerry: That sounds fun, I hope I get to participate as well. Tom: Great! Do you have any preference for any of these events? Jerry: I think badminton would be fun to help out with I used to play it with my siblings. Tom: Cool! I will add you for the event. I think its best to start discussing the format of the event. There are a couple of other volunteers for badminton, i can connect you with them. Jerry: Ah, I forgot to ask, has there been a date picked? Tom: Its next saturday. Actually Depending on how long we get the place reserved, it may slip to sunday as well. Jerry: That's coming up soon! Tom: True! The volunteers have already sent out some emails and collected some funds. Now, we mainly need help with the logistics and organizing the event. Jerry: Phew, yes I can help with that. Tom: Perfect! We have a meeting today at 4.30 pm. Is it fine if i add you to it? Jerry: yes happy to help.

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Hello there! Tom: How has your morning been thus far? Jerry: Its alright. Went grocery shopping and got to stroll around in the rain. How about you? Tom: Today is a work day! How did you have time for that? I'm going through a lot right now. Jerry: Oh, you mean going through a lot of work? I usually take Wednesdays off because I work the weekends! Tom: WHAT? Why would you do that? Take the least interesting day of the week off and work on the most interesting? Jerry: I actually don't have a choice. I'm an acupuncturist and all my clients want to be treated on the weekend! Tom: Wow. The game is brutal like that. I've always been sceptical of acupuncture. Like...does it even work? Why? How? Where is the literature? Jerry: I went to school for it and so I find the literature quite convincing. I've also seen its benefits firsthand in my practice. It revolves around the Chinese notion of Qi. Tom: Lol. Bro...I don't buy it unless it has a paper that was presented at a conference and peer reviewed by 6 independent parties. Who wrote the literature? Where did it originate? Jerry: Haha. All good questions! I don't have studies on hand at the moment, but perhaps I can send some to you later! What do you do for work? Tom: I'm a comic. Jerry: Oh wow! What's your best joke? Tom: It's not appropriate to say here but I assure you it's VERY funny. Jerry: Haha fantastic.
items.question: What does Jerry do for work?

items.conv: Tom: Hi! Jerry: Oh hey. How's your day been? Tom: It's good! Just went to the park to enjoy the sun. You? Jerry: The sun is a bit too bright for more. Maybe I'm on the verge of becoming a vampire. Tom: Haha, beach season is coming! You need to look tan! What did you do indoors all day? Jerry: I mostly work. Sometimes I try looking at at beach photos and pretending that I'm actually going to the beach. Tom: hahahaha, that's pretty funny. Ever thought of bringing your work things to the beach?? Jerry: All the times. My work involves a few types of fish and a few types of nets. I just put the nets on the fish to see how the fish will react. Every time I do that, I think of going to the beach. Tom: Hmm I see. It sounds like you work near the water already, no? Are you some kind of fish researcher? Jerry: Yes that's close. My research focuses on jellyfish and pufferfish. Many of them a poisonous, but if processed correctly, they would make hi-end foods. I try to find the best recipes to bring these fish to the tables. Tom: Woah! This is very interesting! I have honestly never heard of such kind of work. Is it dangerous at all? Jerry: Yes and no. Because it's obviously dangerous, we all have to wear protective clothes. Thus, accidents almost never happen. Tom: Hmmm, yes I have heard that. Apparently most mountain climbers fall not on the most dangerous routes, but on the easier routes, when their guard is down! Sounds like the same psychological phenomenon. Jerry: Yes, it's the same philosophy. You seem to know a lot about mountain climbing. Do you climb a lot? Tom: I'm pretty amateur! I like to climb at indoor climbing gyms and have never gone outside on dangerous routes actually. Ever tried it yourself?
items.question: What fish does Jerry's research focus on?
